page.title: 02NATIONAL TRUST FLORA
page.content: The three heathers, Ling, Bell and, in marshy ground, Crossed-leaved heather form with Bracken and Gorse the ground cover of the open moorland. Holly and Honeysuckle are also useful foodplants found in sheltered valleys. In the more sheltered lower ground and on the clay there is a greater wealth of flowering plants and more shelter for animals. In spring the sunnier southern slopes have Cuckoo flowers, Stitchwort, and King-cups. The main tree now on Blackdown is the Scots pine. When grazing ceased it was the first to grow along with the Birch. There are also Oaks, Whitebeam, Rowan and Beeches. At Marley Common are Beech, Wild Service Trees and Sweet Chestnuts which are coppiced for stakes and fencing.
